Definition: Classify the given comment whether it conveys anything impolite, offensive, or mockingly abusive by providing "insult" or "non-insult".

Positive Examples.input: Comment: No wonder Hillary got beat by a circus clown.
Positive Examples.explanation: This comment is insult because it is scornful and disrespectful.

Positive Examples.input: Comment: I guess when you're clueless you stick your head into every hole.
Positive Examples.explanation: This comment is non-insult because it does not disrespect any group.

Negative Examples.input:
Comment: Hillary Clinton was not my girlfriend.

I did not have sexual relations with that woman.
Negative Examples.explanation: This comment might be obscene but not insult.

Comment: This article is rubbish. What it completely misses is that while you are paying for your house, you are also getting somewhere to live. That money that you pay for a mortgage would otherwise go to rent. Not only that, rent is subject to inflation, whereas mortgages are only variable based on changes in lending rates. So for a mortgage, maybe average 4% interest over 25 years and work out the cost. But for rent, take this year as the baseline and then add an inflation rate, currently at least 3-4%, but even if only 2% when compounded over 25 years is a lot of money!! Plus half the costs he attributes to owning a house, such as furnishings, baby gadgets, etc, are incurred regardless of whether you rent or own.

Absolute garbage.

Comment: Hikers at least have opportunity to use good judgment: "Hmm...this area is completely encircled by head-high brush.  I can't see far in any direction.  I'd better not go in there."

Runners have less time/opportunity to do so by virtue of the rate at which they're moving, but can still sometimes change course to avoid danger.  Mountain-yuppies hurtling at speed down low-visibility trails have still less opportunity, again simply by virtue of rate-of-travel.

Which as been the point all along--moving rapidly through low-visibility terrain in bear country is dangerous--doesn't matter whether you're running, biking or sliding down on a piece of cardboard.  Moreover, the danger isn't only for you, but for others on the trail endangered by your irresponsible behavior, and of course the bears themselves.

I oppose bear-baiting.  Even by reckless morons who volunteer to be the bait--because, AGAIN, they risk others' lives besides their own.

Comment: So you think Quintillion, a for-profit company, has hired Alcatel Lucent and is spending billions on the Arctic Fiber cable to bring internet to a few remote communities on Alaska's west and north coasts? Doubtful.

Arctic Fiber is a way to cut microseconds off of trading algorithms buy and sell times between Japan and European stock exchanges by using the most direct route possible by cutting across the Arctic Ocean. It's financed by banks and big financial trading firms, especially Cooper Investment Partners. Alaska happens to be on the way, and Quintillion in their wisdom have secured federal subsidies to run offshoots from the cable to connect these local communities... it is also good PR to do this, and the cable benefits by power injection at regular intervals as well. But the notion that Arctic Fiber is being installed solely for these communities is laughable.

So my fact-based comments seem asinine to you (meaning "stupid or foolish") -- how do you figure?

Comment: Our LCBO is just a long standing remnant of prohibition.  Basically, alcohol sales are banned in the Province of Ontario.  A person or company cannot sell alcohol to another person, period.   

There are two exceptions, beer sales through a privately owned "brewer's co-operative" and sales by the province through the Liquor Control Board.  

So, if you want to sell alcohol in Ontario, what you do is sell your alcohol to the LCBO, at whatever price they determine it is worth (no competition, so you get what they give you) and the LCBO resells it at whatever markup they please (usually 200 to 300%).  

What we have now is a public service union that wants to get in on this cash bonanza with the usual full time, high salary "jobs for life".  The only grounds for all of this, is that the govt is "protecting us" from the evils of alcohol, by selling it to us at hugely inflated prices, and preventing anyone else from doing the same.  

That is it.  It's a morality play.  Stupidity.

Comment: No, I am really not. Philosophy - from the Greek "philos' meaning love and "sophos" meaning "Wisdom", the love of wisdom - is literally the study of how to think straight.

If you haven't learned philosophy, you will never be able to form a logical thought. No, what people think they are doing isn't logic. Logic is a set of rules. To think logically you have to know those rules, and apply those rules (much like algebra is a set of rules you have to know and apply to get the right answer).

To think you can be logical without studying philosophy is like claiming you can do algebra without learning to count first. 

Here's how it works:
Philosophers figure out how to understand things.
Scientists use those techniques to understand a particular thing.
Engineers use that understanding to solve practical problems.

Unfortunately - because true logic is so often counter-intuitive, those not schooled in it tend to think actual logical arguments are "stupid" because their intuition says so.

Comment: What a bunch of IDIOTS. The most fair and COLLECTIBLE tax is a SALES TAX. 
The success of a tax is if it is widespread, can be enforced easily and is paid by those who actually purchase goods and services. 
The fewer collectors of a tax the better, and there are much fewer businesses to collect a sales tax than there are residents, who may or may not honestly pay an income tax There are a LOT of income tax cheaters and to enforce collection of income tax requires a new State agency. 
Auditing businesses who collect sales tax is very straightforward and very few businesses of any size cheat on sales taxes. 
As a person increases their income, they buy more expensive items, therefore they pay more sales tax, Most states eliminate groceries from sales tax, so as to not unfairly hit the poor, so the sales tax is on items people CHOOSE to buy. Rich people buy planes, expensive cars, expensive homes, expensive "toys", remodel homes, buy new appliances, etc. and therefore pay more sales tax.

I actually think Trump has lost us South Korea as a functional ally, and moved US back to Japan.

How is it that he was sent to the North American College (U.S. seminary equivalent of West Point) when he came from a non-college seminary environment?  Did anybody involved at various stages of his formation ask about his life, his social and political affiliations, legal issues?  Anything?  How did he manage to keep this hidden during at least four years of spiritual direction at the NAC?  And even if one bishop accepted him for seminary,  did the ordaining bishop bother to ask some probing questions before making the final decision to ordain him?   These are questions for the Dioceses of Reno and Las Vegas, not Arlington, VA.

Comment: In Baltimore, which removed four statues before today's sunrise, the Taney Monument was a copy of the Annapolis original and was installed in 1887, 30 years after he wrote the Dred Scott decision, which was eight years before the end of the Civil War. (He was a Maryland native but never part of the Confederacy.)
The Confederate Soldier and Sailors Monument went up in 1903, and the Confederate Women‚Äôs Monument in 1917.
The Robert E. Lee and Thomas J. ‚ÄúStonewall‚Äù Jackson Monument, honoring the two Confederate generals, went up in 1948, though it was privately funded before 1928. The lone woman among six sculptors competing for the job was chosen in 1936 to create it. The pedestal bore a spray-painted "Black Lives Matter" after the statue's removal this morning.
Feel free to attach the appropriate context, or research it more, as you wish.

Comment: Platform of the Know-Nothing Party

The basic premise of the party was a strong, if not virulent, stand against immigration and immigrants. Know-Nothing candidates had to be born in the United States. And there was also a concerted effort to agitate to change the laws so that only immigrants who had lived in the US for 25 years could become citizens.

A lengthy residency requirement for citizenship had a deliberate purpose: it would mean that recent arrivals, especially the Irish Catholics coming to the US in great numbers, would not be able to vote for many years.

Know-Nothings organized nationally throughout the early 1850s, under the leadership of JAMES W. BARKER (RUFF, RUFF, RUFF), a New York City merchant and political leader. They ran candidates for office in 1854, and had some success in local elections in the northeast.

In 1856 former president Millard Fillmore ran as the Know-Nothing candidate for president. The campaign was a disaster.

Trumpty was born 150 years too late.

Comment: The learned professor makes the same mistake that everyone makes when discussing the office of Attorney General:  claiming that the AG is the "chief law enforcement officer of the United States."  He is not.  In fact, the office of AG does not exist anywhere in the Constitution.  The office of President is the chief law enforcement officer of the United States, and all in the Executive branch are subordinate to him/her.  As such, I would think that the President does indeed have the right to expect loyalty from his/her attorney general.  A better solution than the one that Professor Dershowitz proposes would be to tightly circumscribe the performance of any special counsels appointed to independently investigate Executive branch malfeasance.  Tightening up the scope of independent counsel investigations, limiting them strictly to the issue they were in fact appointed to investigate, rather than the fishing expeditions they routinely become, would go much farther in this regard.

Comment: Thank you for bringing attention to the COST of health care, and its crippling affect on innovation.  The gigantic, endless political debate over "Obamacare" almost entirely missed the point -- that the COST of care is unsustainable, and the fact that no matter what the system, we all pay for it.  People with insurance through their jobs still pay by having lower salaries than they would have if their employers did not have to pay the huge cost of health care.  My husband and I have been able to have a small family business only because we were willing to take the risk of no insurance.  We were lucky, and now we are on Medicare.  I have no doubt that many other families forgo their desire to have their own businesses because they can't afford the risk.  At least Alaskans have Denali Kid Care, so they do not have to risk their children, but it is still a public cost.

Comment: I agree. I'm pretty sure I've had a close view of the compartmentalization of childhood trauma, where the compartmentalization had enabled a state of functional not-remembering that saw the person through to her mid twenties.  Then the compartmentalization broke down in a series of disabling flashbacks. Though the memories, or "memories," remembered  through  flashbacks seemed credible,  without the external corroboration of events and circumstances by other parties, belief would have been a matter of trust, intuition, and solidarity with the suffering person, rather than material certainty. In the event, sadly, the bad stuff did happen. But one oughtn't  generalize from a valid instance to other instances. Nor should we generalize from an invalid instance.  Each case has to be assessed on its merits. It's in the nature of such crimes that they are too often hard to prove.

Comment: Lets not get bogged down in the minutia here. All of these cuts that are listed in this article are luxury items. When the country is in dept of the tune of ~19 trillion in operating cost  and ~ 200 Trillion in unfunded liabilities and the state of Alaska is ~4.5 billion in the hole, it is absolutely criminal and crazy to sit here and talk about luxury items that I pay for with my tax dollars, like they are essential rights that the government should pay for. You can have all the funding you want when you are in the black.  But when you are in the red, which we are and will be for generations to come superfluous spending is insane.  I applaud the budget cuts, not because I support the President, but because of plain and simple economics.  You cannot sustain anything when you don't have the money.  And we don't have the money.  Also our Congressional delegates are saying what you want to hear.  If they can't see the writing on the wall then they are fools that will enable the downfall.

Comment: Now that we have turned the corner and  light is returning, it is time to really ask what our particular area can do to generate jobs. In southeast, there are lots of resources and limited access to them, such that an area which used to have a healthy, non-government economy is at great risk.  Solutions?

I"m thinking that a place like southern southeast (Prince of Wales Island) could market health by doing things like constructing a soft track for runners, and marketing that in areas that are too hot to live in half the year. This could lengthen the relatively short summer season to 6 months, bringing much needed cash to the area. Not only would personal income increase, but tax revenue would go up as well. That is just an example of an idea for my area; each area of the state has its own particular assets. We need to learn to more efficiently use what we do have.

My heart goes out to the families affected by this downturn: best luck!

Comment: Well, I don't know.   As someone who takes public transit a lot and uses a monthly transit pass, I don't experience much, if any, support for consumers who try to do what they can to reduce their use of fossil fuels by walking and taking transit whenever possible. 

As one example, tax credits for transit passes have been eliminated.  That's just one measly little example.

And generally, with regard to sustainable investing, I'm more interested in energy producing firms that are open and above-board about their practices.   Everything we do requires energy of a sort,...it's just a question of how much, the impact, and the efficiency with which the energy is produced and consumed.

There are other industries that commonly engage in practices that I consider to be much more problematic for society generally.  That topic is for another day!

Comment: It is not that simple. If you simply reach an agreement with a foreign (or domestic entity) to receive information from that entity it can be a Federal conspiracy and a felony if the information was stolen or otherwise obtained illegally, whether or not you actually get the information or pay for it. Stolen email could also fall into that category of items that are covered by Federal laws. At a minimum you would likely be indicted for conspiracy. Money does not need to change hands, neither does the illegal information. Depending on who is involved there could be other crimes for illegally acting as a US Agent (if you are not one), or for US Agents there are a variety of laws, including failure to report the arrangement. And any lie or act to conceal any evidence or investigation of a possible conspiracy can be obstruction of justice (like Papadopoulos) . Or in the case of Papadopoulus whose visits may contradict others.

Comment: Public housing and subsidized housing tend to create a bit of stratification.  Those who are able to get into subsidized housing pay lower rent than they otherwise would, but those who cannot get into subsidized housing pay higher rent then they otherwise would (by virtue of the subsidized housing "squeezing" supply).

This is a big problem for those who are "not quite dirt-poor".  As soon as they earn a bit more suddenly they find they not only have to pay more in taxes but they also see their benefits, such as subsidized housing, taken away from them.  Depending on the structure of the system it can create a real barrier for people trying to work their way out of poverty, particularly when combined with all the other means-tested government programs that get clawed back.  Some people can actually find that they are worse off by earning more.

Comment: The idea of each of us paying in accordance with the rules shouldn't be all that controversial.  But let's also agree who is really paying the freight. When all forms of tax are considered, the top 10% of Canadian income earners represent almost 40% of the total national tax base -  the 2nd highest in the G7 (only behind France).  Pretty progressive. To qualify as one of the 1%, one merely needs to earn as little as $220k. If that's our country's benchmark for Top 1% (and tax 53% of their top income away) our country has done a dismal job creating economic opportunity for its entrepreneurs.   If we're talking 'fairness' - what is being done to enable the 70% of the population who do not have defined benefit pensions to save?  I work, save and invest to build a 'pension'.  Every purchase and sale is re-invested to grow my pension. Then there's the institutional desire to "get ahead" of bad PR, and avoid potential lawsuits, by publicizing the issue and releasing solemn statements explaining everything you're doing to fix it‚Ä¶ even for relatively minor incidents.

And then there's the culture war, fed by online publishers who profit financially from clickbait stories, and by social media users who build social capital sharing stories of outrage and counter-outrage. The Globe plays this game too.

Combine all of the above, and you get a machine that takes situations that might've been resolved to everyone's satisfaction with a personal apology, and transforms them into public and embarrassing displays of humiliation and rage.

Comment: You are completely wrong about mercury in salmon. Pregnant women are not told to abstain entirely from fish. Long lived fish species bio accumulate mercury; salmon, being relatively short lived, collect very little. Where do you get this info? Dams are and have always been the beginning of the end for salmon. Take a little time in the evening and read up on depression era dam projects built in the Northwest on the Columbia and tributaries, follow the decline of the greatest wild salmon runs in North America in years following (here's one simplified source http://www2.kenyon.edu/projects/Dams/bbe02har.html). Reservoirs lead to warmer water, among other things, and they by nature block the ability of salmon to migrate upstream. Both of these effects are bad for salmon.

No dams on salmon streams or their tributaries!

Comment: Unfortunately, it appears that Elagabalus has bought, hook, line and sinker, into the mythology that the liberal media has created around President-Elect Trump.  For one, the bankruptcies of various parts of his business were, by and large, the result of a fall in the real estate market, and a decline in gaming in Atlantic City.  Only once was it the result of a bad economic decision, and that was when he purchased the Plaza Hotel - a decision he recognized was bad, but that was made out of emotion and love for the hotel.  

Furthermore, the bankruptcies were all within the law, and designed to keep the businesses operating and people employed, which would not have been the case had bankruptcy not been sought; real people would have lost their jobs.  Also, in each bankruptcy, Trump was required to surrender assets and ownership stakes worth considerable amounts of money.  So, the claim that he "personally profited at everyone else's expense" is an obvious lie.

Comment: For the PIP-Man, it's likely this is strike two. PIPs take work to put together and take months to administer for the supervisor and employee. Comment: Personally, I'm very disappointed.  I do believe there are better methodologies that FPTP.  But, having said that, I do understand that there is no strong consensus on how it should be replaced, and weak, at best, consensus it should be replaced at all.
If the political environment is not right, it should not proceed, and I would agree that to be the case, all things considered (US civil unrest, world economy, climate change).  However, it is worthwhile to continue to explore the change, and attempt to work toward a better system.  It may have all been too much, too fast, but that is no reason to abandon the idea altogether.
I won't say it will stop me from voting Liberal in the future, because that is a decision of the moment requiring far more brevity than an off the cuff claim, but it certainly will make me question the truth in any promise the Liberals are campaigning on.

Comment: Another tip about pastry bags. I've been baking for decades (including yummy and easy things like macarons), and always disliked pastry bags for a few reasons: they're expensive, hard to clean, messy to use, etc. Instead, I take a middle road between pastry bags and using a plastic bag as suggested in the article.

You can buy pastry bag tips without the pastry bag itself. I use those, and cut the corner off of a heavy-gauge plastic ziploc style bag (I prefer the kind with the zipper for this). You can then easily attach standard pastry bag tips to that.

That way, you can fill the bag and zip it closed, preventing messy accidents that can happen when you aren't holding a pastry bag properly. This doesn't help the cleanup much, though, unless you're willing to throw the plastic bag away after each use. I wash mine.

Comment: California is an "at will" State.    So Google is not obligated to have a reason or pay compensation.      That's not to say they wouldn't, but that they have no legal obligation to Notice.

In Canada, you might not need a reason but employees are entitled to notice, unless fired for cause.     Canada doesn't recognize "at will" employment so we actually have more protection here.     Also, Canada is far more generous with notice than most States.

With regard to reasons - Any employee can be fired at any time with or without a reason.    The question for the fired employee is "notice".

Comment: John: You've given the "textbook" answer stating only the SC can overturn an earlier SC decision, or having  a Constitutional Amendment. However, it doesn't work like that in real life. Here are three examples: In 1982 Congress amended the Voting Rights Act of 1965 to overrule Mobile v. Bolden; in 1988 it overruled Grove City College v. Bell by passing the Civil Rights Restoration Act, which broadened coverage of Title VI of Civil Rights Act of 1965, and in 1991 Congress passed another Civil Rights Act that specifically reversed no fewer than five SC cases. (Source: The American Prospect, Dec. 19, 2001, article by Leon Friedman).

Comment: Foreign investors fuel the housing market.  They raise property values which raise property taxes for municipalities. Higher values benefit the majority of society because 75% of the population own their primary residence.  Higher values lead to more local spending on local goods and services.  More consumption and home equity can be used for more domestic investment in local businesses.  Some foreign investors generate income tax on Canadian income as well. 

And investment in the local property market fuels employment in construction, marketing and advertising, legal, engineering, finance, brokerage, furniture, insurance, etc. 

And foreign investors send their children to local private schools that pay teachers salaries and of course other operating expenses. 

Foreign investors fuel demand for hotel rooms, car rentals and purchases, etc. 

Remove foreign investment from Vancouver and you'll probably find yourself out of a job.

Comment: The law of unintended consequences at work here ... people move to
urban settings because of the 'cool' factor ... costs increase ... cool 
decamps, or simply dissapears. 

For a while small businesses persist ... because of leases or hope ... 
suddenly the market crashes. The consequence ... shuttered storefronts.

The cumulative burden of taxes is killing businesses. Every tax increase 
cascades down upon small businesses. Which of course decreases demand
for the goods they sell. Which reverberates throughout the market place.

Slackening of demand causes wholesalers to close their operations. And of
course this has the knock on effect of reducing tax receipts. Bureaucratic
spending aggregates. No single cost increase seems like much. It is the 
aggregate of all the costs cascading down which eventually reverberates 
up. 

Travellers in the U.S. surely notice these effects. Shuttered main streets 
was the beginning. Now the suburban stores are shuttering ‚Äî bankrupt.

Comment: As someone who has done Jurisdictional Determinations of waters of the US for over 500,000 acres of watershed, ephemeral waters are considered waters of the U.S. by the Army Corps unless it can be proven they do not possess a significant nexus with a downstream traditional navigable water. 

The 2015 Clean Water Rule would make "All waters located within the 100-year floodplain " waters of the U.S.  This is a Federal overreach in my opinion as most of the cites in Colorado (Denver, Boulder, Fort Collins) are built within the 100 year floodplain. That means if you live in these area and simply want to put a garden in your backyard you would have to apply for a 404 permit. Turn around time for 404 permits very from 3 weeks for small nationwide permits (< 1/10th and acre) to 18 months for larger projects. The cheapest ones will cost you about 10K$ and larger work up into the millions.

Comment: Naive to think Canada could significantly impact China's legal or political structures. Mind you, that's not much different than a bunch of other countries - some of which are perceived as rogue states and others that are embraced as global leaders.

It's not whether we refrain from dealing with China in a futile expectation of changing its ways but how we come away from any negotiations with all our fingers and toes.  Whether its a cyber non-aggression pact, extradition treaty or free trade agreement, it's hard not to think of it as the cat and the mouse agreeing not to eat each other.

Comment: "HE stock doesn‚Äôt behave like a normal stock, not even a utility stock. It‚Äôs more like a bond price."
In one respect it does, as interest rates rise the price of HEI will fall, it's called an inverse relationship.  

Odd that you find a "remarkably stable" utility dividend an attribute. A stock with a dividend that has been stagnant for 16 years is not an attractive investment.

Knowledgeable investors seek out stocks with rising profits and increasing dividends.  As an example NextEra paid a dividend of US$2.20 in 2011.  Currently it pays a dividend of US$3.48.

Additionally your wealth is impacted by taxes and inflation, nothing ever remains the same, accept in academia. 

Finally, for people who buy, hold, and reinvest their dividends, a fall is scary.  The value of the shares purchased with dividends at a higher price decreases.  The multiplier effect accelerates the erosion of invested capital.

Comment: Harry Truman didn't know of the existence of an atomic bomb program prior to being sworn in as President.  The decision was his and his alone.  Instead of supposing why he did it, consider his own words:  "I asked General Marshall what it would cost in lives to land on the Tokyo plain and other places in Japan. It was his opinion that such an invasion would cost at a minimum one quarter of a million casualties, and might cost as much as a million, on the American side alone, with an equal number of the enemy. The other military and naval men present agreed. I asked Secretary Stimson which sites in Japan were devoted to war production. He promptly named Hiroshima and Nagasaki, among others. We sent an ultimatum to Japan. It was rejected."

If we had the bomb, but did not use it and two million more people died as a result, what would people say?  War is indeed hell.  It is not civil and a dead person is a dead person, no matter how they died.

Comment: Depends on the job, and who normally does that sort of work.

One academic paper on the topic I read 20 years ago posited the notion of "the competent incumbent" in hiring decisions, and assessment of male and female applicants.  If the job-type was predominantly male, OR female, the mental image of the competent incumbent would be bound up with gender stereotypes, such that the one gender or the other would be perceived more favorably (call up your notion of what a firefighter looks like).  Not any sort of "We don't want your kind here" bias.  Rather those candidates simply *seemed* more capable or qualified.

As the gender balance in the workplace shifted (and I seem to recall the tipping point was around 1/3 or more of the under-represented sex), gender-stereotypes entered into the mental image of competent incumbent less.

Comment: It depends on the situation. Look at Dutch cities that have extremely safe bike infrastructure. Many cities have 40% of all trips taken by bike. People of all ages ride, and no one wears helmets. They are on comfortable, upright bicycles, and going at very moderate speeds. The infrastructure provides protection from cars, and there is very little risk of head injury from any other type of accident. 

Mountain biking or road biking, where you're going fast and can crash and injure yourself pretty badly all on your own, a helmet is a great idea. 

The truth is a helmet is very little protection against what a car will do to your body. If we actually want to make it safe to ride a bike in Denver, we need safe infrastructure. That is the most effective way. I'll keep wearing a helmet in hopes it might help until then, but it's not in any way a solution to the problem. 

Far more head injuries happen IN cars. If you're so concerned, do you wear a helmet when you drive?

.

.

Smart ones take extra water, gear layers, in a pack & bear spray. Low trail has bears nearby in brush.
.
Vern Tejas thanked me. Wasn't until later I was told his name.

Comment: Zero risk - no.  Marginally higher risk levels for money that has no short term requirements absolutely.  Instead of depositing money in a savings account buy the bank stock and easily double if not triple your annual rate of return just on the dividend.  Want a bit more security of capital find a perpetual preferred bank share issue and forego the capital appreciation potential.  For taxable accounts the dividend tax credit leverage the real return even higher.

Market growth GICs are another way to gain some upside potential for those fearful of the stock market.  These GICs offer the guaranteed equivalent of basic bank interest as a minimum and up to 5% annualized as a maximum.

My point was essentially that if one is truly so risk adverse as to leave $100K+ in a savings account that the maneuvers being suggested aren't likely all that palatable.  For those willing to accept a very modest amount of risk there are reasonable options without any requirement of being a savvy trader.

If you were a government worker, you could get GEICO, but nobody else could. I paid about $25 less per month then with All State as I pay now. Yes, I was in my 20s, but my brother was older and he reports a similar experience.

To say it can't be done and then refuse to try it is to buy into their statist bull. We  don't know that it won't work until we've tried it.

And, by the way, in the 1980s, the eilite status quo junkies said opening auto insurance across statelines wouldn't work because laws in each state were so different; it would be chaos. But we tried it and it worked.

Comment: The sphygmomanometer was invented in Europe in 1881 and further developed in Mexico by its inventor, Samuel Siegfried Karl von Basch.  It wasn't brought to the United States until 20 years after its invention.

https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Sphygmomanometer#History

Blood testing and identification of blood groups were a result of Karl Landsteiner's work in Austria.

https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Karl_Landsteiner

X-Rays were discovered in Germany.  Research was furthered in Europe.  

https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/X-ray#Discovery

In all cases these technologies were discovered in Europe, and the U.S. ripped them off (much like the internal combustion engine, our nuclear programs, space flight, etc.).  Taiwan, like many other technological nations, does R&D in the medical industry and has produced breakthroughs like other countries.  Only difference is they're not arrogant like Americans are.

Comment: As with so many things there is a long history of this one, one that dates back decades.

Through the 1970's and especially the 1980's and 1990's the old Ontario Hydro built up a lot of debt caused by a combination of political gaming and mismanagement.  By the late 1990's there was over $30B in debt in Ontario Hydro, which the Province was 100% responsible for but it was kept off Provincial books.

Mike Harris' PC government tried to fix up this mess and the disaster that was Ontario Hydro.  Part of that was to split Ontario Hydro into multiple companies with appropriate levels of debt assigned to each, which is where OPG and Hydro One (among others) came from.  However ~$20B of the ~$38B of the Ontario Hydro debt belong with the Provincial government (keeping in mind the Provincial government was 100% liable for all the debt).  Of that $7.8B became the the "Residual stranded debt" and the Debt Retirement charge was meant to cover.

Comment: I don't think they can deny coverage, but coverage for insulin is subject to copays & deductibles, where for some reason contraception is not. I have a family member recently diagnosed Type 1 and his family has to cover $6000 of deductible before insurance will cover his insulin. That should take them to about December, & January 1 the deductible starts all over again. That's not real coverage.

I have another relative who has to pay for EpiPens for her son to make sure he lives through an accidental exposure to a food allergen, again, out of pocket until she's fulfilled the deductible.  That's not real coverage.  

Yet for some odd reason, contraception has to be covered 100% from day one.  It makes no sense.  And spare me the argument it's "preventative" care (not you of course, but others argue birth control is "different" because it's "preventative").  Insulin prevents coma & death.  EpiPens prevent death.  Blood pressure meds prevent stroke and death. This whole argument is crazy.

Comment: G2,  I'll take a stab at this strictly from my point of view. First, what everyone is calling "clips" should really be called magazines. If a bad "person" was trying to to load his/her weapon via clip, it would really, really slow them down if it was a modern civilian semi-automatic weapon such as the AR family (M4/M16).  But for the purists out there, an M1 Garand (think WWII and Korea) a clip would be correct but it only holds 8 rounds. Spend some time on your search engine of choice and you'll see what I mean.
I own two AR type carbines and lots of thirty round magazines. Seldom do I ever fill them to max capacity but when I do, I do. The main reason is I don't want to bother with reloading so often. There are times when I just want to keep up a sustained rate of fire. Mostly this occurs when I am teaching somebody specific shooting techniques and/or circumstances.
If you haven't, take a trip over to the Bear's Den and shoot their Thompson sub-machine gun on semi and full automatic.

Comment: I have now gone through all the comments-a truly depressing exercise. NOT ONE Refers to the threat of climate change, let alone suggest how to deal with it-other than, leave the tar sands in the ground. We need better answers.

And they are "tar sands", not "oil sands." They were tar sands when they were described >100 years ago, they were tar sands when I worked on them in the 70's. Then some PR flacks decided "tar" sounded dirty, so they changed it to "oil." (One of the reasons we have been fed is that "tar" is a man-made substance. Hilarious. Tar is a perfectly good word that comes from very old roots, and is perhaps 2,000 years old-long before we started making it.)

Properly, of course, we should say "bitumen", but that's a long word. And if you look it up, you will find it refers to a tarlike substance. So by all means, continue to say oil sands- if you wish to identify yourself as falling for PR manipulation.

Comment: Contrary to what your comment seems to suggested, my personal feelings about the cross are irrelevant: they were no more consulted when it was erected than they were when a federal judged deemed it unconstitutional. I prefer that all religious voices be represented, including Christian voices. Also, putting the matter to a vote would accomplish nothing. Local communities cannot suspend the Constitution based on popular vote. Thank goodness for that, or else you may still have communities where slavery is practiced and where women are not allowed to vote. Each member of this community, in a sense, puts this matter to a vote when he or she elects representatives who vow to uphold the 1st amendment; the People could elect representatives to repeal the First Amendment if they so choose, and yet they do not. Further we entrust judges and legal experts to determine the legality of such matters--in this case a Reagan-appointed federal judge.

Comment: Lots of comments here disparaging O'leary.

I am not an O'leary fan, but the fact is that the membership rules were changed to personal credit card or cheque after certain individuals were found to be signing up bogus members by paying with cash during local riding candidate contests in 2015. The new members didn't even know that they had been signed up, which is how this was discovered.

So this story does not surprise me at all.

Bogus membership and donations happens at all levels and in all parties, which is why in Quebec all political donations (provincial and municipal) have to be accompanied by  the donor's signature that must then be remitted to Elections Quebec.

However, I doubt that  Bernier was personally aware.

Comment: IF this is true (which I doubt it is), then it should stop.  Those who use the roads, at any time and for any length of time, should pay for them.  But PUBLIC transportation has to be "subsidized."  If not, fares would be prohibitively expensive, and no one would use it, so it would be a waste even to provide it.  The government has an interest in safety, pollution and congestion, as these affect all of us negatively.  Also, RTD, by law, has the ability to raise its share of property taxes without a vote of the people in the District.  If not for subsidies, RTD would raise property taxes to a level that would cause a revolt among property owners.  RTD was created by the Legislature, and was granted certain special powers.  Areas have opted in by votes of the affected property owners.  
(cont'd.)

Comment: Flesh Eating Bacteria (C. Difficile) on the Rise, Study Vaccine to Prevent Outbreaks

Create: 04/09/2010 - 00:00Author: Science News Desk
 
The thought of being infected with MRSA brings fear and panic to those who know how fatal the flesh-eating bacterial infection can be. Now, recent reports show that a known bacterium is overtaking numbers of MRSA infections in hospital settings, making physicians re-evaluate prevention tactics nationally and leading to a local study which may help with the creation of a vaccine to stop the spread of the illness. 

According to the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention, more than 28,000 people in the United States die from Clostridium difficile, or C. difficile, annually.

Comment: Ironically, the Trudeau/Butts cabinet shuffle in January plus personnel changes to key cabinet committees interfacing with the new US administration were only initiated so that at least a few competent ministers would be involved on NAFTA and other Canada-US files. 

While still embarrassingly weak compared with a US cabinet of seasoned, successful heavyweights with relevant executive and subject matter experience, our cabinet is stronger than the farcical bunch (think "Police Academy I") that was appointed in November of 2015 thanks to Trump.

But the Liberals' emphasis on identity politics and quotas rather than merit has certainly worked for them to keep them in the good seats in Ottawa most of the time since 1935.

For example, without the overwhelming vote of Quebecers for one of their own "identity" in his 5 elections, Pierre Trudeau would have been a one term (1968-72) PM.

So there may not be excellence but there sure are votes in the Liberals' identity politics game.

Comment: I'm certainly enjoying today's 4C dry mid-winter weather in Toronto, with more of the same on tap for the next few days. However, I'm not sure I agree with the definition of "mild" weather described in the article (18C to 30C). To me, mild, or comfortable, daytime highs range from 12C to 24C, although to a great extent this is dependent on the season. A high of 12C in June would be cold while it would be really nice in November. A high temperature over 24C, especially when combined with the summer humidity that's a virtual certainty in places like southern Ontario, is essentially hot weather in much of the country.
